pageSummary: In memory of our wonderful Mum because they were wonderfully supportive
pageSummaryWhat: In memory of our wonderful Mum
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Our Mum, Morag Davidson was diagnosed with cancer shortly before Christmas. Sadly and to our complete shock, she was given only a very short time to live. This was completely devastating and almost impossible to understand but The Macmillan staff and all doctors and nurses at Kirkcaldy hospital were wonderful from start to finish. Both our family and my Mum were very grateful for their endless kindness and support. My Mum was so sad to leave them when she was moved to Kirkcaldy Hospice. We are also eternally grateful for all of the incredible staff at the hospice and will be looking to do a separate fundraiser later in the year as a thank you to them as well. We can’t thank the NHS and Macmillan enough for all the the incredible support they showed us during the hardest time of our lives. We are very grateful for each member of staff who very kindly provided our Mum care and comfort in her final days. 

If you are able to donate anything for this cause my sister, Nicola and I would be eternally grateful. 

Lynne xx

story:
Please read!

I'm running the Asics London 10km this July for Macmillan cancer support and it would mean the world if you could have a read, share this on and if possible donate to a fantastic cause.


As some people on here may be aware, last October I was diagnosed with a rare borderline ovarian tumour. After what can only be described as the most painful and agonising wait of my life to find out what exactly was going on and countless scans I was told I would need major surgery to remove the tumour and my right ovary that had been completely destroyed. By November I had a planned surgery date ready to go however that was apparently not good enough. My tumour decided to start to rupture and I was rushed into hospital for emergency open surgery.

I've decided to run the Asics London 10km this July for Macmillan cancer support to raise some money for the fantastic nurses that have helped me through all of this. This has been one of the most challenging periods of my life and I would love to raise some more awareness so no one has to face this alone. Macmillan nurses, doctors and health professionals will continue to support people effected by and those living with cancer whilst doing all they can to help alleviate the immense strain put on the NHS by corona virus. pageSummary: A secret birthday fundraiser to surprise Dav
pageSummaryWhat: A secret birthday fundraiser to surprise Dav
story:
Dav's Mum has been on a tough journey with cancer over the last 10 years, having both womb, and now bowel cancer, which has returned and returned again.

Dav is balancing family, home schooling, teaching delivery and hard decisions about treatment with the challenges of trying not to transmit Covid from his work to his Mum. Every day he gets up and gets on with it. With a resigned smile he'll say 'what else can I do?'. But despite his brave face, it's really just a bit shit.

Having a birthday in January is bad enough, never mind lockdown, and your lovely Mum being seriously ill. 

This fundraiser is a little something to warm Dav's heart. Something to make him smile and help him realise that we're all here sending our love and support in bucketloads.  Especially when we can't even pop round to say hello.

So many of our friends have been touched by cancer over the last year. It would be lovely to put together a pot of donations in Dav's name to mark his birthday and put some good into the world.

Thanks for giving what you can :)

pageSummary: 40 mins of fitness for 40 days because They are helping me through breast cancer 🎀
story:
My partner Nick Johnson's and I are raising money for Macmillan Cancer, by doing 40 mins of exercise for 40 consecutive days.

In the middle of November I found 4 lumps in my left breast and made an appointment with my doctors. I was seen a few days later and referred to St Albans breast care clinic just for a check up.
At that appointment I met a consultant who felt the lumps and suggested a scan that day, which then led to a mammogram then 6 biopsy’s and fine needles procedures on my lymph nodes. I was told there and then to prepare for the news of cancer but that they couldn’t confirm until results were back, which they were, quickly!
I went back to the hospital and was told I had breast cancer, at 37! To say it was a shock is an understatement, but I am a firm believer that you just do what you’ve got to do to get through it and everything that happens, happens for a reason 💖


By the middle of December I had my date for my mastectomy and lymph node removal, 22nd December. I was in and out the next day, but had to have my nipple removed on 12th January.

In a couple of days I have my appointment with the oncologists, I know I will need radio therapy, we are discussing results with regards to chemo and breast reconstruction as well x 


I couldn’t have got through the last couple of months with our amazing Macmillan nurses, who have gone above and beyond to help and advise me on what is happening and what will happen, comforted me and made me feel at ease in the most uncomfortable situations. 


Please share and tell your family and friends, ladies let’s remind each other to check our breast regularly 💖💖

#breastcancerfighter #checkyourboobs #raisingawareness #raisingmoney #cancerresearch #macmillancancersupport #breastcare #beautifulsenses #fmfragrances #fmworlduk

story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.

I'm collecting vital funds for the British Heart Foundation, to power pioneering research into heart and cardiovascular diseases. The money we raise will help beat heartbreak forever.

British heart foundation has always been a charity close to my family’s heart, with several members of my family suffering with a heart conditions. Fundraising and research became more important to us in May 2019 when my Mummy was diagnosed with Chronic Heart Failure. My Mummy has had to spend most of the last 12 months at home to keep her safe.  

On New Year’s Eve I decided I wanted to challenge myself to raise money. I am aiming to walk 62 miles /100km in 30 days. 

Please please please sponsor me. I want to help raise as much money as I can for the British Heart Foundation. 

It is so important that we continue with fundraising for the British Heart Foundation to support their research into Heart and circulatory disease and hopefully get closer to finding treatments and cures.

story:
As you know my beautiful, funny, beloved brother was taken from all of us on the 23rd of December 2020. He was taken far too soon and all of us feel our own sense of loss. Paul died of a dissecting aortic aneurysm. The British Heart Foundation are running key research projects to help prevent, spot and treat such heart diseases.

“Greater awareness amongst doctors and healthcare professionals - and rapid access to CT scans to diagnose the condition - are key to saving lives." 

Spotting this early currently shows patients survival rates are 60%. With the support of the BHF and monies to support their cause will increase this survival rate. 

 It will not bring my hero back but in his name, I hope it stops other families from losing their loved ones prematurely as we have. 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

story:
In May 2019, I lost my dad due to a sudden heart attack. He was just 58 years old and I was only 14. My 16th Birthday is the 5th of February and this will be my second birthday without my dad. As a family, we thoroughly enjoyed attending RBS 6 Nations matches at Murrayfield and a few years ago we were lucky enough to watch France v Scotland in Paris. My dad always talked about going to Twickenham to watch an England v Scotland match, he never achieved that dream.

As a fundraiser and in honour of my dad Tom Thomson, I have decided to virtually cycle from our home in Ayr to Twickenham, a total of 710.1km or 441.2 miles.This means I will be required to cycle 32 km or 20 miles each day and my aim is to arrive no later than 1600hrs on Saturday 6th February the day after I turn 16.  

This fundraiser is for BHF Scotland, Wellington School Ayr and most of all my much loved dad TOM. All donations will be gratefully received, along with your support to keep me going over the next 3 weeks. Thank you for visiting my page,

 Katie Thomson X

story:
Thank you so much for visiting my page!

For the volunteering section of my Silver Duke of Edinburgh award, I have decided to host a series of fundraising events across the next six months in order to raise money and awareness for the British Heart Foundation. 

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thank you!

pageSummary: I am fundraising because I lost my grandad in August 2020
story:
In August 2020 my grandad very suddenly passed away from a cardiac arrest, the speed in which it happened took us all by suprise. Athough grandads heart did start beating again thanks to the valiant efforts of the first aiders at Huntingdon Garden Centre, paramedics and doctor who attended, unfortunately the damage had already been done and 4 days later grandads life support was switched off. Anyone that knows me will know how much I love chocolate and my grandad certainly helped with my chocolate fixation as a young girl (often hiding my stash in his jacket pocket so my younger sisters wouldn't find it and I would be made to share) Since grandad passed away I have personally donated to the British Heart Foundation, sponsored an engraving in his memory on the BHF Heart of Steel and now I am taking part in the BHF DeChox which shall see me give up chocolate, sweets and fizzy drinks for the month of March 2021. To some it may seem like such a silly way to raise money but if grandad was still here he would laugh at me doing this knowing how much I love those sweet melt in your mouth Dairy Milk bars. 

The Covid-19 pandemic is the biggest challenge the BHF have faced in their 60 year history. And it's led to them being forced to make the devastating decision to cut their 2020 research budget in half. Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help the BHF keep up the pace of progress. Willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need the BHF most because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers.

story:
Thank you so much for visiting my just giving page! For those that have known me for many years, you know this isn’t the first time I’ve raised money for charity. Back In 2013 and 2014 I raised money for children charities by trekking the Great Wall of China and then running the London Marathon. I raised a lot of money around £7000 in total but when I saw this challenge on Facebook I thought this is for me. 

I’ve trained to walk 10 days in China , I’ve trained to complete 26.2 miles running without stopping and I’ve swum the equivalent of the channel to France but the thought of not been able to eat chocolate for 31 days seems like the impossible for me. I’d happily walk 10,000 steps a day , give up alcohol for a year and maybe just maybe train for a 10k but really no chocolate for a whole 31 days ???? 

For those that truly know me ,they know I am a chocoholic. They know that during a night shift I will call at the 24hr garage and buy bags of share bag chocolates and just sit and eat the lot to myself, how I will never just eat a normal amount of chocolate recommended in one sitting , how I find it acceptable to sit and eat a whole tub of celebrations in one go. I am never that far away from the sweet stuff. The truth is I am a chocoholic and there isn’t a day that goes by where I don’t feed my addiction. 

So please believe me when I say , I think signing up for this challenge and doing a whole 31 days will be that ... a true challenge. I recently downloaded an app to help with my addiction and so far I’ve managed a total streak for 4 days and that’s me trying. 

So please sponsor me to complete what I believe will be the biggest challenge I’ve ever signed up for . Knowing you are supporting me by donating your well earned cash is what will keep me going , knowing we are raising money for the British Heart Foundation and all the people they help.  

Thank you ! Please follow me during the month of March on my socials to see how I get on.

pageSummary: I’m giving up chocolate in March because my father died of Endocarditis.
pageSummaryWhat: I’m giving up chocolate in March
story:
I am giving up my much loved chocolate for the month of March in tribute to and in memory of my late father Hugh Morgan (Verdre), during the month of the anniversary of his death. It’s a challenge set by the British Heart Foundation. The reason for me deciding to undertake this challenge is to raise awareness for Endocarditis. 

Unfortunately, due to covid restrictions we were unable to receive donations at my father’s funeral, therefore we will at a later date (when it is safe to do so) organise something in my father’s memory to raise much needed funds for the Welsh Air Ambulance. 


My beloved father and much loved Tadcu died on 30th March 2020 after contracting Endocarditis (infection of the replacement valve in his heart). He received open heart surgery in 2018 to replace his own failing valve. He recovered from this surgery, however later on in the following year he developed an infection in the replacement valve. After months of suffering and failed treatments he was given one last chance of recovery in the form of open heart surgery to remove the infection around the valve. He was given a 50/50 chance of surviving the surgery. During this surgery they also replaced the valve. He survived the surgery, however he returned following it in a critical condition and died 2 days later.


Due to Covid restrictions we were unable to be with my father when he needed us the most. To our heartache and devastation, my father had to endure the most terrifying days of his life alone, and his life ending by him passing away alone at the hospital. 


The purpose for my undertaking this challenge is to raise much needed awareness of Endocarditis. Had we have known about this condition and it’s symptoms following the initial replacement valve surgery in 2018, we feel that the loss of my father could have been prevented. Effective treatment of this condition needs to be undertaken at the earliest opportunity possible. Therefore by doing this challenge I hope to raise awareness of this complication to others who have a replacement valve or may do so in the future. Combined with this, any donations raised in the process will help fund further research for the British Heart Foundation as a tribute to my late father.

pageSummary: I am doing this challenge because all support they get helps
story:
As many of my friends and family know, I love my chocolate so when I saw this challenge I thought to myself.. go for it.

In 2005 one of my close family friends had a heart attack which led their heart to stop beating. Fortunately, paramedics managed to restart it and following having a stent fitted, made a full recovery.. or so we thought. In 2007 the same family friend went into hospital for a routine operation only to have another heart attack - fortunately, not as bad as the first.

I now work in a GP surgery and everyday we receive letters from hospitals of patients who are normally fit and well being admitted with heart attacks. After 6 years of working in a GP surgery you get to know the patients so to hear of them having any sort of medical problem can be upsetting.

These are certainly trying times and the BHF along with every other medical profession are stretched to the max trying to keep people safe and continue researching.

I love my chocolate so this is going to be a challenge and a half for me. 

I appreciate your time reading this and for sponsoring me. 

Lots of love

Jen xx

eventName: Malin Head to Brow Head in 24 Hours
story:
Hi folks, thank you for visiting the page! My coach (Ben Heron) and I have decided to organise an event whereby we run the distance from the most northern part of mainland Ireland, Malin Head (County Donegal), to the most southern part of the island, Brow Head (County Cork) in the space of 24 hours. The total distance between these two regions is roughly 302 miles (486km), making this event extremely challenging! Members of the Level Up Academy along with their close friends and family will be involved in the event, each running varied distances that will contribute to the overall distance achieved on April 4th 2021. We felt that during these difficult times, this would be great opportunity for people to get involved in an event that adds a sense of purpose to their exercise, whilst raising money for an extremely worthy cause. This event is ultimately in memory of my incredible Dad who sadly passed away in his sleep on the 16th October 2017 to a suspected cardiac arrest at 50 years of age. Through raising awareness of cardiovascular disease and the impacts it has on so many families, we are also keeping my Dad's legacy alive and no doubt doing him extremely proud.

I would like to take the opportunity, on behalf of my family and I, to thank you for your donation regardless of the amount. We appreciate every penny.

pageSummaryWhat: I am running LLHM, my first 1/2 marathon in March
story:
I am running LLHM, my first 1/2 marathon in May,  and as I hit 50 this year, it may be the only one I do!

Me and Phil will probably be hobbling around together and my aim is to finish it in one piece!

My granddad was blind and I remember him spending time away from home to train with his new guide dog. He benefitted from the company of Honey, a yellow Labrador, for many years and she retired into our family as both he, and she, became less mobile.

My grandma, his wife, became blind later in life and you could always tell when she'd been doing housework, all her ornaments were facing the wrong way!

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

So, if you were thinking of sending a card for my half century, please consider a donation instead.

Many thanks, Sam

pageSummary: We are fundraising in memory of Krish Kent
pageSummaryWhat: We are fundraising in memory of Krish Kent
story:
Krish was our beautiful five-year-old son, our amazing superhero, he filled our life with light, joy and happiness. Krish was so much fun to spend time with and we are so grateful to have spent five glorious years with him.

At the age of 10 months Krish was diagnosed with 
Neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1) which had developed as a random genetic mutation. Despite the diagnosis we were told most kids live fairly normal lives and we did not know the full impact of this condition. 

When Krish was a year old, he developed a problem with one of his legs and had to wear a splint to help protect it. Other than that, Krish lived a very healthy and happy life. He learnt how to ride a bike, he loved school, he was great with numbers, enjoyed eating out, going on holiday but most importantly he loved spending time with his family. 

Sadly, in October 2020 Krish, aged 5, very suddenly and quickly became unwell. On the 18th October he was admitted at GOSH for emergency brain surgery. As the days went by, we were told of the severity of what was happening to him. He was diagnosed with an inoperable malignant brain tumour. There was nothing we could do to save our son. As parents we decided to fight for Krish and help him get stronger to be able to complete radiotherapy and chemotherapy treatment. This was never going to cure Krish but would buy us some time with our precious little boy. 

As we got ready to start treatment Krish's tumour grew rapidly and sadly he was unable to start treatment. He died in our arms on 9th December at 17:42 leaving us totally devastated. 

Krish was a very strong and brave boy, he was a real superhero.
We had to make tough decisions for him. When we decided to put Krish through treatment, he decided he did not want this, he must have thought he would suffer and so would we. We were then getting ready to bring him home to spend his last days with us, even then Krish decided he did not want us to remember him this way at home. He died in hospital surrounded by his family. 

The speed with how all this happened is still something we are
struggling to understand. During the seven weeks we were at GOSH the care and compassion we experienced was exceptional and we will always be very grateful to the Koala and Intensive care wards.The medical, nursing and support staff were outstanding, we never doubted the care Krish received.

We also now know that the prognosis of these types of tumors is not good and there is very little funding allocated to research in this life destroying field. This type of cancer kills many children, despite this, there is very little funding allocated to research . Therefore, we have decided to help raise funds for GOSH to be able to carry out clinical trials and research in this area.

All funds will be allocated to Koala ward and to research of these specific brain tumors. 

We really want Krish's life to mean something, and we would like
him to continue to be in our memories. For those that knew Krish, you will know he was kind, clever, happy and a very loving beautiful boy. 

Please share this page with family and friends and help us keep Krish in our memories.Any little thing that we can do in Krish’s  memory that can help other children and parents , will be  helpful.

Every donation helps Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity to provide the best facilities and equipment, research and develop new treatments, and support their remarkable patients and their families.

pageSummary: Completing 6000 flight stair climb because COVID has affected cancer patients significantly
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As you may or may not know, my closest friend and the most special person in my life, my Mum, was diagnosed with cervical cancer during the pandemic. This affected us all as a family, especially with not being able to support her in the way we all wanted to due to COVID-19... making it more difficult to accept for both herself and us!

I decided to set this challenge for myself over 5 days ago, firstly as a fitness challenge but then I thought I could support an amazing cause by doing this today.

I will be climbing 6,000 flights of stairs in my home over the next month. 39,000 steps up and 39,000 down steps down, per day. 

I know these times are difficult for everybody in different ways, especially financially. I am asking for just a small donation, even just a single £1 to help towards fundraising for a charity which is so closest to me and my family right now. This pandemic has slowed down lab research and affected cancer patients lives in all different ways and worst of all, it has delayed vital life saving treatments.

Alone, the fight for cancer cures will never stop, we could all make a huge difference to peoples lives who need it the most.

story:
So have had a very close dealing with Marie curie when my Nan and Amelia’s great nan died of cancer. Unfortunately Amelia only got to meet her a few times before she passed away but loved her so much. Marie curie were amazing when they cared for her and was so supporting of the whole family who never left her bed side 24hours a day, with her best friend, her soul mate, her loving husband who done everything he could to make her comfortable and loved till the very last minute! Marie curie are so close to all our heart and we are forever thankful for the time and care they put into nan while she was at her end of life. Grandad also unfortunately passed away September 2020, who is now finally reunited with his love. We would love nothing more then to give a little back to Marie curie for the amazing help from them in such a sad and difficult time. Both my nan and grandad were foster caters for years and fostered 100s and 100s of children giving them the best life possible loving and caring for them as their own. This will be in memory of them both as we will never forget you, your always in our hearts love you both always and forever.

It would be much appreciated if you could donate however small it is to give us the chance to thank Marie curie for their love and care

Thank you!

Mommy and Amelia ❤️

story:
Thank you for visiting our JustGiving page.
Since the pandemic began in early 2020 we have had to cancel events and have been unable to be out and about talking to you about the work of the RNLI in and around Hartlepool
This is having a huge effect on donations which is why we are coming out to our friends, families and supporters virtually to ask for your help - we rely on donations from you, the general public and without your support we wouldn't be able to continue saving lives at sea.
The Covid-19 pandemic has brought a new risk to our volunteers that we never could have predicted or imagined but our brave and courageous crew members continue to risk their lives to save others.
We hope that you can support us by donating on our page - we look forward to seeing you soon, stay safe.



Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all Yorkshire and the North East lifeboat stations is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the pounds start to add up. Since the Covid-19 pandemic, we haven't been able to fundraise as normal to keep our lifeboats afloat. Your donation to this page will help support the running of our 19 stations in Yorkshire and the North East; Amble, Berwick upon Tweed, Blyth, Bridlington, Craster, Cullercoats, Filey, Flamborough, Hartlepool, Humber, Newbiggin, Redcar, Scarborough, Seahouses, Staithes and Runswick, Sunderland, Tynemouth, Whitby and Withernsea

story:
Who's up for a little it of fun during lockdown? We're hosting a colouring competition for kids (and adults!), so get your kids involved and let their creativity flow.

Even better, an RNLI supporter has very kindly donated prizes for the best coloured picture to be judged by our volunteer crew members.

A £25 voucher for Gourmet Shakes and Snacks for 10 years and under, and a £25 voucher for Gourmet Shakes and Snacks for 10-16 year olds.

Entries to be sent to Douglas Lifeboat Station, Battery Pier, Douglas, Isle of Man IM1 5BT.

Why the RNLI?

On the Island, the RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown. 

Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives has not stopped. Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds has been limited.

The average lifeboat station on the Isle of Man costs £161,000 a year to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income due to the Coronavirus.

We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running.

Our crews at Douglas, Ramsey, Peel, Port Erin and Port St. Mary will always be there to keep you and your loved ones safe, on our watch, there will be no preventable deaths on our Island.

Please help us fulfil that mission.For ideas on how to support or get involved please contact nick_evans@rnli.org.uk

Your donation to this page will help support the running of stations on the Isle of Man as follows: Douglas, Ramsey, Peel, Port Erin and Port St. Mary.

Thank you for your support.

Every donation, no matter how big or small, makes a difference. 

Together, we won't live with poverty.

We would like to raise money for Unicef's Yemen Crisis Appeal, just £33 provides a child with food for 3 weeks!



🚶‍♂️Our aim is to collectively (as a team along with our clients) travel the distance from Bedford to Yemen which is 3670 miles by 1st March and raise £5000 along the way!



🚴‍♀️This will be done by walking, running, cycling, rowing or skiing, you name it! on a daily basis! Every little helps here, every mile counts!

pageSummaryWhat: I am running London Landmarks Half Marathon
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. 

WaterAid is an international not-for-profit charity, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.

Click the WaterAid logo on this page to go to their website.


To make this race personal I will be attempting to break my half marathon personal best time of 1 hour 33 mins. I'll be drinking clean water along the way.

Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in climate-vulnerable communities.
